div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7239] ALEXANDRIA, Thursday, APRIL 6, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p: This Company's system of submarine telegraph cables is the most direct and quickest means of communication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa, India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.
For latest average time to London, see daily bulletin in this paper.
STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo, Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Head Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency. 31-12-904

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste
Steamer leaves Alexandria on about 10th and 24th May.
Far East Line

(Departures from Suez) To Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama, Kobé about July 5 and August 4. To Aden, Karachi, and Bombay accelerated service about August 18. To Aden, Karachi, Bombay, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about July 20.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: Pagnon's Hotels, Luxor
div.p: Luxor Hotel- This old established htoel, accomodaying 130 guests, is situated amid beautiful gardens with entrances on the river. Resident Doctor and Algican Chaplain, Billiard rooms, Bar, Electric Light and all the conveniences of a first-class European Hotel. Tennis Court
Karnak Hotel- Under same management. Beautifully situated on river. Nice gardens. Guests taken on pension. Moderate terms. Excursions arranged to Thabes,Karnak, etc.

div.head: Ghezireh Palace Hotel
div.p: On the bank of the Nile. Formerly the PAlace of late Khedive Ismall. Transformed into a luxurious hotel.
Splendid Park
Renowned for its afternoon-teas on the West Balcony overlooking the Park. Excellent Trigane Orchestra, Motor-car running to Shepheard's Hotel and vice-versa.

First Class Family Hotel with Every Modern Comfort.

Moderate Charges. -- Special terms for Government Officials and Officers of the Army of Occupation.

div.head: Enormous Damgage done
div.p: Vestcrnay moiniiy, a severe earthquake t.Mik litul «lso m ii northerly tliivou ■ ; ...ii Simla. Enormous damage v n. in-, :i . i u ns leased there has boon h . u.),: i .11 in.’, i:»piHally nt Lahore where , iay mu.allies eolnipscil. TheTawous mosques; Bombay, April 5. N ino Europeans and a considerable num-.. a ol natives weio Killou at Lahore. It is ibaied Uiat some Europeans were killed at the Alinsoouo Hut Station, to the South of Simla, v iu.ro not a blunting escaped the catastrophe, h is reported that every house at Dharmsala has noon Jeveiieit and that sotne-Europeans and in ■ iy natives Jiavo lit on kniotl. Delia suffered 'usiderauiy,-but none were killed, brum many iiei places tneie are no reports, owing to the interruption of the telegraphs.

div.head: family Jar
div.p: The daughter of Sheikh el-Sadai, whose matrimonial escapade created such exoiteuieut last summer, .has ieit her lather s troupe together with several members ot Ills lamtiy and household, and will probably stay some time with Princess Nazn lianem. Murderers Sentenced.—The Assize Court ol A siuul has eoudemue.i to death one Ahoui liussali4 iiamuda, who murdered Sueikn Mu-dapiia Abd ei Ghani near Aleliawi station, iiamuda’s associate, Aialirous Mustapbu, has been sentenced to hard labour for life. Stray anu Ownerless Dogs found in the Baida Zeynab quarter of ' Cairo during the night ut Friday aud morning, ol Baturday, aud in the Boulao distrsct 'during the night ol Saturday and the morning ot Bunday, will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: 16 vessels passed through the Cabal oil the 3rd inst., of which 7 were British, 1 Austrian, 1 German, 3 French, 2 Norwegian, 1 Dutch, 1 Egyptian. The day’s receipts were lrs. 377,732,Ui, making the total from the 1st inst. lrs. 1,157,362.50. Alexandria's (Jars.—There are almost two thousand oabn m Alexandria, and the annual inspeetiou is being earned out' by the police this week, it is not expected that more than two to three bundled cabs will, be con- demned as unsatisfactory. The general stand- ard ut tne cabs in Alexandria has greatly improved within the last tew years, "Poisson d’Avril."—The identity has not yet beon discovered of the practical joker, who succeeded in twice summoning Superintendent Lynn and the Alexandria Fife Brigade' to1 ( h i Ion’s establishment ou a false alarm of fire on All Fools’ Day. The person in question made uno of a telopliono in a pastry cook’s shop fur iho purpose. If discovered, it is possible t!uT civil proceedings will be instituted by the Alexandria Municipality against him. The Lottery Law comes into-force on Mon- d ty noxi, the 10th inst. It is stated that tho prohibition of the sale ol lottery tickets in the streets is the reason for the great and conti- nuous rise in the Credit Foncier Lottery ’bonds. Che issue ot the Italian Benevolent Society’s lottery tickets at Cairo has been suspended un.til a license has been obtained from the Government.

div.head: Alexandria Assizes
div.p: The Assize Court sittings will begin ou-April 12. There is a very big list of eases awaiting trial. Tbe trial of tho native butcher and shoemaker, who recently murdered an old woman under circumstances of great brutality, and disposed of the corpse in the Mahmoudieh Canal, will not be held until May 1. The two Greek ray alii, whose coining establishment was. lately raided at Karnious, will also be tried at the May Assizes. An Incident of a curious character is stated to have.'Occurred at the Geueral Assembly, according to “Al Mokattam.” Iti the proefes verbal'ot the first fitting of the Assembly mention was made of the Financial Advisor as being among those present. Ac the next meet- ing Sheikh Aly Youssef brought forward a motion that the above-mentioned statement in the proces-verbal should be withdrawn as being unconstitutional. 'Hie Slfoitcli’s-motion, however, was unanimously rejected and he thereupon asked leave to retire. Egyptian State.Raiiavays. —The Board of Administration informs us that the trains -“de luxe ’ ruuniug between Cairo aud Luxor will be suppressed from Cairo on and from Monday, loth inst, aud from Luxor on aud from Tues- day, 11th. The last "luxe’’ traiu will leave Cairo on Saturday, 6th, and Luxor ou Sunday, ‘Jib inst. Commencing from same date, dining and sleeping ears will be attached to the night trains leaving Cairo at 8 p.m. aud Luxor at 5.30 p.m., three times a week, as follows :— From Cairo, every Monday, Wednesday,' and Saturday ; from Luxor, ovory Tuesday, Thurs- day, aud Sunday.

div.head: Local theatre fire
div.p: The Abbas Ilelrny Theatre at Alexandria was destroyed by fire at an early hour this morning. Yesterday evoning, the usual performance was given by Gatti’s circus troupe,which ended at a quarter past midnight. At 12.20 a.m. the dynamo which supplies the electric light for tho theatre was stupped, and by 12.40 a.m. everyone connected with the theatre had left the building, nothing untoward having hap- pened. At half-past one in the morning, however, the alarm was Jgiven to the Fire Brigade that the “Abbas” was on fire, and on arriving on the spot a few minutes afterwards they found the large building in flames. The fire, which had apparently originated under the stage, had Spread with 'alarming rapidity to the auditorium and boxes, and in a short time the theatre resembled one vast roaring luruace. 'Fortunately, no one was in the building at the time; aud there was. no loss of life. 'The horses belonging to the circus troupe were, however, stabled under the stage and efforts were at once directed to saving the, animals. This was done, though three of the horses unfortunately were charred by the flames before they could be got out. v Little or none of the belongings of the unfortunate artistes belonging to the circus troupe cou.d be saved, as the conflagration had got a strong hold of the building. The efforts of the Fire Brigade were mainly directed to saving the walls of the theatre and the sur- rounding buildings, and it reflects great credit ou them that the lire was so successfufly kept wiihiu hounds, none of the adjacent buildings being affected. Bhortly after the outbreak the toot of the building collapsed with a tremen- dous crash, aud now nothing remains of the theatre but ‘the four walls, the whole place being entirely gutted. By 5 o’clock tms morning the fire was thoroughly mastered by tne Brigade, but the hremeh are still engaged in pumping water ou the smouldering mass ol charred wood- work and distorted iron pillars. The cause of the outbreak has not as yet been ascertained, and the sympathies of all .will be with the proprietors, Aiessjs. A.G. Moulerrato, when it is known that their loss is lyot covered by insurance. Thp theatre was built in 1834 aud was valued at something like £16,0011.

div.head: EGYPTIAN LAND AND GENERAL TRUST
div.p: Of the £200,000 capital asked for the flota- tion of the Egyptian Land and General Trust, Ltd., subscriptions to the extent of £300,000 have already come in up to mid-day to-day. Of this total, Egypt has subscribed £80,000 and England £220,000. The allotment of shares will, it is hoped,be completed by Sunday night.

div.head: crime
div.p: The Procnreur General thus oonolndes his review of crime:— That the inorease in orime, properly so called,' is less by half in 1904 than in; 1903, while criminal robbery has not risen (it has in fact fallen by 20)—that the rise in dMits is small in comparison with that of the last years, and no more than what might be fairly expected ; that such increase as there is accounted for by petty oases of assault and by a more -exacting standard in the Matter of false accusations while theft and crop-destroying have decreased, and cattle-poisoning not in- creased ; all this, while it oannot be oalled a brilliant result, at least indicates a less marked tendency of serious orime to remain on the increase, and is, so far, a matter for satisfaction.

div.head: MEHKEMEHS
div.p: The state of things, at present, is far from encouraging, and it is not astonishing that native reformers should be at length awaken- ing to the urgent necessity of serious re- forms in these Courts. Notably, in suits concerning private Wakfs, scarcely a week passes without some more or less serious com- plaint being received at this Ministry. The majority ol these private Wakf suits are pure questions of property and private rights and do not in any way affeot the religion of the people. Some of the more enlightened among native reformers therefore consider that the wisest and most satisfactory solution for all concerned would be for the Mehkamehs to hand overfall that relates to private Wakfs (Wakfs Ahly) to the Native Tribunals, retain- ing their competence in charitable Wakfs only (Wakts Khairy) which, being, of a more spiritual nature, fall mbre properly within the jurisdiction of religious Courts. This would certainly be a solution of the difficulty and itt> leasibihty is under the consideration of the Government. r

There has been some attempt, in quarters hostile to the project* _ to make capital out of the case of Mr. 'Beck and the stinHulus which that deplorable affair has given in England to a revival ol the agitation for a Court of Criminal Appeal. It may therefore perhaps be desirable to say a lew words on this subject. The suggestion is, of course, that the Egyp- tian'Goverument is proposing to abolish tlyi very safeguard which that case has shown to‘be imperatively necessary. Two considerations suffice to demonstrate -the fallacy iff this con- tention. The .first is that there is no real analogy between the functions of the Egyptian Court of Criminal Appeal—which it is proposed to suppress -here^—and those of the English Court ot Criminal Appeal—which it is desired to introduce at home. The one reviews, on the papers, jthe findings of (act of Tribunals which have heard the witnesses; the other would eitheT rehear the case de novo, witnesses and all, or else order anew trial at which the witnesses would be reheard. Whatever ad- vantages, therelore, might attach to the latter sj8tem—>they are highly problematical, the question being, as is generally admitted, an exceedingly controversial one—they are clearly not poMeased by the Egyptian institution which only exceptionally hears the witnesses. The secoud consideration is that the learned Commissioners appointed to iuquire into the Beck case, and report thereon to-the Home Becretary, have not, as a matter of fact, seeu fit to recommend the institution of a Court of Criminal Appeal, which they apparently regard —aud, it is submitted, rightly (1)—as calculat- ed to impair the dignity aud finality of the stti unices of the existing Criminal Courts. They content themselves with reoommending that some machinery should be provided for secur* ing the possible oousidcration, by a superior Court, of crucial poiuts of law decided by the judge at the trial. Such machinery already exists, in the Egyptian system, in the powers of the Court of Cassation, before which any oonvicted person has the faculty of showiug that a point of law bas beeu erroneously decided, to his disadvantage, and that he has consequently not had a fair trial, or that his oonviction is bad in law. If he suoceeds, the Court of Cassation either quashes the conviction or orders a new trial. We may, therefore, dismiss the idea that, the Beck case has any real bearing on the question of Assize Courts for Egypt. The qnes tiou remains yrhether, in any other respect, the situation has undergone any change since last year. Unfortunately it would appear that, it there has been any change, it has been tor the worse, crime having again increased, as may be seen from the report of the Procnreur General, though not, I am glad to say, in the same ratio as in the preceding year.

div.head: EGYPTIAN CIVIL CODE
div.p: After citing various oases to prove the defective drafting o * the Egyptian Civil Code, the Judioial Advisei remarks :— But it is not only in the drafting that Egyp- tian legislation is defective but also in the total omission of a number of important subjects and the locume and obscurities in the provisions regarding others. Thus Egyptian legislation contains no law of copyright, no law ef patents, no )»w of trade mark* and Egypt has conssqueitly been unable to adhere to the various International Conventions relat- ing to these most important subjects. There are constant compla inta from the commercial communities as to he loss and inoonvenienoe caused to them by the absence of a satisfactory law on these questions of every-day applica- tion. Again, the lan i law is very defective. The law of easements {servitudes) is so brief and incomplete as to givi i rise to constant difficulties. Wakfs aqd contracts of a similar nature are governed exolusivsly by Mohamedan law, which varies according to the different rite* not to mention the divergences in the views of the various authorities of the same rite. Obviously the only remedy for a body of legis- lation so radically defeotive is to simplify the modus legiferendi in Egypt. That the Egyptian Government should be oompelled to apply to fourteen Powers whenever it is desired- to efieot an improvement in Codes of the oalibre above described or to provide legislation cm subjects of the importance above referred to is obviously absurd

div.head: LAND REGISTRATION
div.p: In regard to the provisions of the above project, the Judicial Adviser remarks: “It would undoubtedly effect a very considerable change in the existing system and there can be very little doubt that the change would prove beneficial to the community at large. Indeed the defects of the present system are almost universally recognised and its continued existence is mainly due to the circumstance that it has hitherto proved impossible to formulate an acceptable’ scheme ’ to take its place. Now, howeve^ that such a scheme Jras been voted by a majority of the technical delegates, it is greatly to be hoped that political considerations may not induce the Powers to vhto the projeot and deprive Egypt of the benefits of a reform for whioh she has been struggling for so many years.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: Yesterday the troopship “Dilwara” left Southampton with artillery and infantry drafts and various details on board for Gibraltar and Malta. Amongst the officers is Major C. L. E. Eustace-Robertson, D.S.O., King’s Royal Rifle Corps, who joins the 1st Battalion at Cairo. The “Dilwara” is due at Malta on the 2nd April and at Southampton on the 11th follow- ing. Her return will dose the trooping season of 1904-03. Captain Claude 3. Hawker, Coldstream Guard* commanding the Camel Corps of the Egyptian Army, has just been promoted to field rank in the Guards. Major Hawker entered the Guards close on fifteen years ago, the last six of which hare been spent in the Khedivefa service. He earned' tile Egyptian medal with clasps for the operations against the Khalifa in 1899, shortly after he joined the Egyptian Army. .A Captain S. J. Somerville, Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, attached lately to the Indian Army, has been restored to the establishment of the inniskillings vice Captain R. C. Piero* appoint- ed adjutant of the 8rd Battalion. A feeling has been created that the War Office is trying to conceal the names of the fraudulent contractors in connection with the Cape Stores scandal. On the other hand, Mr. Arnold-Forster has given all the knowledge he possessed on the matter. There is every reason to believe that every difficulty was put in the way of his doing so. The battleship "London” (Captain Philip F. Tillard), which was commissioned at Ports- mouth on the 7th Juu* 1902, for service with the Mediterranean Fleet; will return home from that station on 24th prox. She will pay off the following day at Portsmouth, and will be recommissioned for another tour of service in Mediterranean waters. Her crew will be partially drawn from the battleship “Ramillies” in the Chatham-Sheerness Reserve.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET
div.p: The recent Japanese successes in the field hate been followed by a wonderfal triumph in the financial world. The fact that as the war wanton the Japanese were able to get better terms, and had the shrewdness to take ad- vantage of them, will always be reoognised as an additional feather in their cap. By how many unnecessary millions they have secured this bloodless viotory, is the question everyone is asking tb-day. Some say it beats all records, excepting only that notable one—the Trans- vaal War Loan, of a similar amount This was subscribed 39 times over and serves still to remind the world what the United.Kingdom can do in times of stress, as compared with disunited Russia.

Naturally these large applications, coming in conjunction with'the Stock Exchange settle- ment, have caused a shortage of ready money, but too much attention need not be given to this, as when the money is released, which is promised at an early date, there is every like- lihood-of continued ease. In fact, these efforts on the part of the public to collect money, and grasp a profit^ to be had for the asking often, have the effect of increasing the floating supply of capital Nevertheless, oven after a period of comparative freedom from new issues for several years, it is not advisable to overdo the calls on the publio, and this is realised by the leading financial houses, who. are quite alive to the situation.

Generally speaking, stock markets are in- ; active this week, and the arrangement of the ! Account has occupied dealers, to the exclusion Of fresh business. The large number of new issues now on the market—particularly t^e new Japanese 4} per cent, stock referred to Move—have kept the public out a good deal, 1 find have, moreover, caused a distinct scarcity of money in the settlement. There is a decided feeling that the rush of new issues has been Sufficient, and that it has, for the time being, I put a check on the activity that was bo marked i _ in the investment stocks during the early part ] of the month.

Egyptian stocks, after starting the week dull, have rallied sharply during the past two days, 1 led by Agricultural Banks, which have been I bought largely for Continental account— i especially from Paris. The price has come up I over £2 to 12f; It is rumoured that a further 1 issue, both of Ordinary and Debentures, is in preparation, and' the present upward move is very likely "paving the way” for this. National Banks are a good market at 21 J, whilst other shares are steady, nth' little change. Salt & Sodas are a dull point .at If on the new issue. Amongst the new companies, Corporation of -Western Egypt have risen to $, on forced buying. The mining section has sagged off somewhat again, and prices show a distinct set-back from last week’s-account, but the 1 market is not a bad one by any means, and ! ought to be worth attention at present prices, lor the drop is certainly only a temporary one.

div.head: EGYPTIAN LAND AND GENERAL TRUST LTD
div.p: Los demandes de so ascriptions pour lee ac- tions de la dite Compaguie seront revues aux bureaux de l’Anglo-Egyptian Bank au Cairo et h Alexandria les jours suivants: lee 5, 6, et 7 Avril. jusqu’k 5 heuree de l’aprfis-midl Passe oette date, aucune souscription ne sera plus admise.

(another of the Taylor group), • the prospectus of which reads' well, and which is sure to obtain favor, com- ing from suoh a source. The capital is only £35,000, of which £10,000 will be allotted as fully paid to the Egyptian and Sudan Mining Syndicate, Ltd. The concession is that granted originally to Mr.' George Ogilvy Haig.The area of the oonoesston excludes that known he the "Dareheib mines," comprising 2,560 acres, but with this exception, it extends over some 18,000 square miles. Messrs. John Taylor & Sons are to act as managers and consulting There is a very strong undertone in the South African market and those who ought to know predict higher prices, especially in Rhodesians. The rise in Chartered is partly traceable to shortness of shares whioh are very scaroe and recent developments are very encouraging in Copper Gold.

div.head: Mesoptamia
div.p: From Sawauia .to Suk es Shoyuk ■ tho Eu. phrates has on approximate longtli of 190 kilo- metres. . After passing Sawama and before it reaches Nasrieb, the Euphrates freely over- ilowa' its banks and forms'extensive swamps whilo its own channel naturally diminishes in six*. From -ivasrieh to Suk es Sheyuk the HISTORY OF'fTHK EGYPTIAN . OASES. width of the river may be taken as 50 metres, and the depth as between one and two metres. From Sink es Sheyuk to Gurnu, where it meets the Tigris, the length of tbo Euphrates may be taken as 120 kilometres. Prom Suk es Slieyuk to Barga the wiuth of the rivormay be taken os oOmetiea and the depth aa between one and two metres. At Barga, where the river Hows between, comparatively speaking, high banks, the width of the Euphrates is only some 15 metres, while (he river is deep and has a stroug current. Below Barga, the Euphrates flows through extensive swamps, forming a sbuliiw bar’acioss the swamps, over which tiie water in lLod is l.5u metres deep anil >u COCKS. BY PROFESSOR SAYCE. Until systematic excavations can be made >uk the Eu *n 088(53 earlier fiistory must, remain i of 190 kilo- to a large extent Unknown. All we can say at' and before PreseDt-is that the Egyptians were acquainted freely over- vith theta from an earlier period, ajid that live swamps the Egyptian kings claimed sovereignty over iminishes in “fem 88 far V0* at least as the age of the Shevuk the : Eighteenth dynasty (B.C. 1600-1400). Our namn la. Iil>a ll.a A i akin ir/.l aama. low supply about -TSmcues. From tome point ^urk,"r' 1" the time ofthe Eighteenth dj'nasty between Euk es Sheyuk and Barga the ancient the elaborate chusitication ol a later ago had between.Euk es Shoyuk aud Barga the ancient Palueopus cabal.used to take oil' the right bank of the Euphrates and flow past tlie ancient city which was known as Basra iu the time of the Khalils and'which is known as Zobeir to-day. It is about 20 kilometres south- west. of the Modem Basia. flic Euphrates swamps cud ■ at Medina, and from here the • river flows ju a channel some 100 or 150 muties wide, uu . to Gurna, where it is met by. tbo Tigris. The joint risers are known as the Busra river, which flows past the modern Basra ' to the Persiuu Guif. The comparative lengths of the river inuy be thus euuuiorutod:— For the greater part of the information be- tween Sawama ami Gurna 1 am iudebtod to the Rev. Juhu Van Ess of the Americau Mission at Basra, who has travelled over all this conutry-aud also that on the Hai Canal; ■ In its present- condition the Euphrates is , navigable from Gurna to Sawama aud up the Hiudia Canal to. the Hiudia Barrage near Mosaib for boats drawing about 1 metre of water neatly throughout the year. ' From the Hiudia Barrage, pmlt Mosaib aud Feluja, on to Hit, navigation is also open all the year round to ordinary native boats drawing 125 metres of wuter. About the year 1870 two small steamers plied betweeu Feluja (the lauding place whence goods go by caravafl to Bagdad, a distauco of 60 kilometres) aud Meskene (the landing pluee whence goods come by caravan from Alepp); hut after a year or two, one ol tbo steamers was wrecked at the island ol Ardeshir and tho other stopped ranning. fhore are bridges ot boats across the .Euphrates at Aim above Hit^-at Feluja, Mo- saib, Hille, and Dewania. Many canals take off the Euphrates. They will be described in paragraph 9 when the delta of the two rivers is under consideration. name, for them, like the Arabic icah, comes through the Greek from the Old Egyptian mh, though in ancient Egyptian they were more usually called ut, the western lands to which the spirit was supposed to depart after death. In tho Ptolemaic inscriptions at Edfu seven oases are enumerated: Kenem or El- Kharga, with its capital Hib, “the ploughed land” and its two important towns of Kash, nqw'Dnsh, and Usekh, now Qfita; Zeszes or Dakhla ; To-Aht, “low-land” or Fartffa ; UAh orel-Hez; Sekhet-amu “the Palm-grove,” or Slwa; "the oasis of the north” or el-B and "the Salt-Field,” the modem Wadi eu- Natrfti.- There is r,o refcroici to tin oasis o‘ Knrkur. In the time of the Eighteenth djynasty

div.head: History of the Egyptian Oases
div.p: Menet, the founder of the united monarchy of Egypt, was originally king of This, near Abydos, and from the way in which the name of This is sometimes written in the Egyptian hieroglyphics we may gather, not only [that a road-ran frjm it to the oases, but also that This and tho oases were ^tinder the same government -The oldest monuments, however, as yet found in the oases are not earlier than the Eighteenth dynasty.Tho oasis of el-Bfthariya is called in .the inscriptions “the northern oasis of Amon-hotep,” implying that along with el- Kharga and el-Dakhla it has been resettled by Atnou-hotep I, aud a stela of Thothmes II. has been discovered, there . to the west of Bawitti. One oh tho large scarabs of Amon- hetep III: has also- bocn found in el-Dakhla ; otherwise the earlier remains that have hitherto.been brought from tho latter oasis are two monuments dated in tho reign of Shishak IV; (about 850- B.C.), which were obtained by Capt. Ly6ns from the neighbourhood of Mat. They are written in oursive characters, and the larger of the two relates to a disputed claim as to the proprietorship of a particular spring. The case was brought before the Egyptian governor upon bis arrival in the oasis, but after a delay of several years was decided, not by, him,. but by an oracle of the god of the place. Both the governor and several-of the other officials mentioned on the two monuments bear Libyan names, and it is clear that the oasis was inhabited at the time mainly by Libyans.

Beyond a tomb belonging to the age of the nineteenth dynasty and tho fragments of two temples of the twenty-sixth dynasty (B.C. 550) which exist in the oajusofel-BilhariBga,nothing more has been met with in any of the oases which is earlier than the Persian epoch. The great temple of el-Kharga was either founded or rebuilt by Darius in honor of Ammon-R-i, andthekiugis described as having erected it of "good white stono" and as having covered its.doors with bronze from Asia. There is a long list of the offerings presented to the go.l which begins with "the wine of the Oasis,” as well as a hymn of praise to the Sun-god, -The tompli was afterwards enlarged by Nektanebo .1. Not far to the. south, near Geand, is an- other temple which dates from the time of the Ptolemies.

It was under tho Romans that the oases seem to have attained theirohiefimportance.Thiswas the poriod to which most of the ruined temples, forts, towns, and aquoducts owe their origiu, though it is,very.possiblo that the Romans mere- ly restored or improved earlier constructions. Both the "Greater" and "Lesser Oasis,”—the modern el-Kharga and el-Dakhla,—as wellas the “Email Oasis," or el-Bdbariya, were thoroughly cultivated and strongly garrisoned ; a brisk trade was carried on in yriue, and the oases were used as places of exile as, it would appear, had already been the case under the Pharaohs. Among the distinguished individuals who were banished to them was Nestorius ; Juvenal; is said to have been anothor.

That a considerable amount of taxation was raised from them may . bo concluded from an j inscription on one of the outer walls of’the temple of el-Kharga which is dated ip the 2nd year of the Emperor Galba (a.d. 69). The' inhabitants of the Thebaid had complained of extortion on the part of the tax-oollectors, and tbe’prefect of the Oasis aicordingly commijni-j cated in it the answer of the governor of the .’ province, admitting the validity of the com- ’ plaints, forbidding future extortion nnder se- vere penslties, and ordering the restitution of all illegally exacted monies. Another inscrip- tion iu tho same place, but of earlier dat, contains a decree forbidding soldiers and oth r publio servants to exact food or lodging with- out payment when travelling though "the nome." Any snob exaction wu to be punished bya fine to “ten timesthe amount of what had bon exaoted," while the inforaer was to receive "a fonr-fold portion" as his reward. And it was further enacted that “tho royal scribes, the village clerks and the clerks of the dis- tricts it) o.-v-li nnme, sliall keep a register of all that L expended by tho nome upon any- ono ; so that if any irregularity has been com- mitted, it may be recorded and sixty-fold repayment made."

Temples wore erected in the oasis ol el- Kharga by- Donation and Trajan (at Dush), Antoninus Pius (at Qasr Ain ez-ZayAn), and Hadrian (at NAduraJ; and in that of Dakhla by Vespasian and his bodb (at DCr el-Hagar). Extensive cemeteries of the Roman age have also been, discovered, containing mummy-cases on which a portrait of the deceased has been sometimes moulded in stucco, sometimes paint- ed in oils upon wood. But the most remarkable monuments of the Roman age a\e the subterra- nean aquemiota of el-BAhariya. Here numerous channels have been out through the rock at a considerable depth, below the surface of the ground, tapped-.by shafts from above and intended to condaot the water into largo underground reservoirs. ’ Tho aqueduote are now for the most part choked with earth or rubbish, but they need only to be cleared for the oasis to become once more one of the most fertile of lands.

Oiympiodorus, who’was born in the Thebaid in the tourth century, and therelore spoke with authority, describes the Egyptian oases as specially celebrated for their fertility and healthiness. The trees, he deolares,."are constantly loaded with fruit, the corn growu iu them being more excellent than any other command whiter than Bnow. Barley is some- times grown.twioe a year, and millet almost always three times a year.” The system ol irrigation was very perfect: “well*, sunk to a depth of two or three hundred or even live hundred cubits, pour streams of water from their mouths,” while the peasants wero in the habit of watering "their little enclosures every third day iu summer aud every sixth day iu' winter, which is the cause ol the great fertility of the land, though the sky is always cloudless,” Oiympiodorus further noticed that "the rocks of the mountain' which extends from the Thebaid into the oasis" were full. of “marine shells aud oysters,” and drew the conclusion that the oases had once been islands. * .In spile of the .raids of the Nubians, whom Diocletian endeavoured to buy off by baudmg over to them the district betweeu the First aud Second Cataracts, the prosperity of the oases continued iuto Coptio times, as is attested by the ruined monasteries and Christian cemeteries which are scattered over them. With the' withdrawal of the Roman garrisons, ’ however, . aud the. Mobamedou conquest of Egypt their decay set iu; the aqueducts were choked, the fields neglected, andmtlarial fever invaded a district which had once been regarded as a health resort.

div.head:
Dr. Le Clerc's
Pills for the Liver & Kidneys
div.p: are an unfailing and reliable remedy for diseases of these important organs, gout, rheumatism, gravel pains in the back and kindred ailments (acquired or constitutional). Sold by principal Chemists, not in loose quantities, but only in boxes, price 2s. 3d bearing the British Government Stamp with the words "Eugene Le Clerc" impressed thereon to protect the public from fraud.
Dr. Le Clerc's Soap.

Medical, antiseptic, used and recommended by eminent dermatoligists in the treatment of ecsema, lepers, psoriasis, ulcerations, skin eruptions, itching and irritating skin humours, baby rashes, etc., also a prophylactic against the risk of contracting disease and infectionus disorders generally. Its healing properties greatly minimize the inconveniences of shaving in cases of pimples, spots, In Tablets price 1/- sold by Max Fischer Alexandria.

div.head: Thos. Cook & Son,
div.p: (EGYPT), LIMITED, HEAD OFFICE—LUDGATE CIRCUS—LONDON.
CHIEF EGYPTIAN OFFICE — CAIRO, near SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL.
Alexandria, Port-Said, Suez, Luxor, Assuan, Haifa, & Khartum.
GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country! 10 12-904

div.head: Egyptian land and general trust
div.p: CAPITAL......................... £200,000, Divided into £200,000 Shares of £1 each. With power to increase to £500,000 upon Resolution of the Board. Are now issuing a prospectus -by which the Directoirs invite Subscriptions i at par for £200,000 Shares. PAYMENTS MOST BE MADE AS FOLLOWS—2/- on Application, and 3/- on Allotment And the when required, in Calls of 5/- each, at intervals of not less than one calendar month. TO THE COMPANY'S BANKERS: - in LONDON,—BAROLAY COMPANY, Limited, 64, Lombard Street, E.O. In EGYPT,-ANQLO-EQYPTIAN BANK, Limited. 5 Share Warrants to Bearer will be issued when required. Shares maybe paid up in full on or any time within two months from allotment.
Directors

DIRECTORS. SIR WILLIAM F. HAYNES 8MITH, K C.M.G., LLD., Isis High CommissioBtir-of'' Cypres (1898-1904), 8, Bentinok Street, Manchester Square, W., Chairman. MAJOR CHARLES HYDE VILLIER3, 1, Great Cumberland Plaoe, W. ARTHUR PASTON MACK, Managing Director Nile Valley Company, Limited, ‘ * Palmerston Home, E.C. ■ FREDERICK RUSSELL ROBERTS, no occupation, Little Wood, 8unningdale, Berks. JAMES WOODROW MATTHEWS, Merchant, of Matthews,' Wrightson & Co., 65 Sl 56, Bishopsgate Street Within, and Lloyds, E.C. DIRECTORS IN EGYPT. AYERST HENHAM HOOKER, F.LC, F.C.S. Boulak, Caito. HIS EXCELLENCY CROOKBHANK PASHA, British Commissioner of the Dafra Sanieh Compauy, Limited, Cairo. NIKOLAUS LONSDORFBR, Merchant, Cairo.
Solicitors

This Company is formed for the purpose of carrying on the business ot an Investment,Exploration^! Development Company, especially in Egypt and the 8oudan. ^ For some years private Syndicates have been exploring oonoesffons granted by the Egyptian and Soudan Governments with tery satisfactory results; districts previously unexplored have been opened up, aud laud hitherto of little value is now steadily improving in price, and is in great demand. The irrigation and reclamation schemes projected are likely to still farther increase the investment demand for laud In view of the above, it ia proposed that this Company shall pay epeoial attention to business connected with land development irrigation schemes, aud reclamation works. It is generally admitted that the many industries of Egypt, unler the careful supervision of the Government, are now malting stead, progress. It is - intended to act as financial- agents in JJoodoi^ Fans and elsewhere for laud development, mining and other oompanies, and i. is anticipated that considerable profit will result from this source. In view of the increasing interest of Freooh Investors in Bgyptian Securities, it is proposed to open a Branch Offise ia Paris at a.: early date. As the success of Company of this nature is to a large extent dependent upon a thorough knowledge of looal conditions, it is extrem ely satisfactory to have secured the servioes, as Director and Agent-General in Egypt, of Mr. Hooker, late Geueral Manager of the Bgyptian Salt and Soda Company, formerly Direotor-Ueneral of the Egyptian Government Salt Department in Egypt ;his knowledge of the oonatry and local business conditions is probably unequalled. Mr. Hooker has consented to act tor a period of three years, at a salary of £1,000 per anuum, with a farther remuneration equal to 5 per cent, of the net profits in eaoh year available for distribution among the shareholders ^whether distributed or not) in excess of an amount equal to £10 per cent, on the capital paid up on the Sharee of the Company for the time being issued. 100,000 shares forming part of the present issue have been underwritten at a commission of 3 per cent, with an over-riding commission of 1 per oent which will be paid by the Company. 'Hie Directors are interested as sub-underwriters, and each will receive the 4 per oent on the number of shares underwritten by him as follows: — Sir William F. Haynes Smith, 2,000 Shares; Major Villiers, 10,000 Shares; AIL Hooker, 5,000 Shares; F. Russell Roberta, 5,000 Shares; J.W. Matthews, 6,000 Shares j H.E. Crookshank Facha, 500 Shares. The preliminary expenses, including registration lees and stamp duty, legal expenses aud brokers' fees, the ooet of advertising aud issuing this Froepectus, down to and including the allotment other than the underwriting commission and brokerage, are estimated s £4,000, which will be paid by the Company. No promotion money has been or will be paid. The Company will pay a brokerage of 8d- per shares to Bankers on all shares applied for and allotted to the publio on forms bearing the Banker's and Broker's stamp. Applications tor shares can only be made on the form accompanying the prospectus which ooc tains the particulars required by law. Frospeouisea and Application Forms can be obtained at the Uttioes at the Company, the Bankers, Broken and Solicitors, or from the Secretaries, and wiU be sent on reoeipt of a telegram addressed "Hooker Cairo." j This advertisement it not intended as an mntaqon to subscribe.
